snippet: Haitians and foreign aid workers agree that television should educate the masses and promote social conciliation. But that goal yields mixed results.
abstract: Alessandra Stanley describes the mixed messages Haitians get from television, where public service announcements air alongside commercials for products most of them cannot afford; notes some of the few locally produced programs and points out that people mostly watch pirated foreign shows that do not reflect the reality of their lives (Series: The TV Watch: Haiti).
lead_paragraph: Haitians and foreign aid workers agree that television should educate the masses and promote social conciliation. But that goal yields mixed results.

headline.seo: In Haiti TV Tries to Educate, With Mixed Results
headline.main: Where Cholera and the Good Life Rub Shoulders
headline.print_headline: Where Cholera and the Good Life Rub Shoulders
headline.content_kicker: Critic's Notebook | The TV Watch: Haiti
